text: Happy to help Luke :slightly_smiling_face: I'll be sure to keep everyone up to date with any potential changes we see going forward!

(I'm trying to answer a question for someone) - Does anyone know if there's a way to blacklist specific IP's from accessing your HubSpot CMS website? They are on WordPress now using a plugin for it... looking to see if anyone knows a work arounnd.
Not really fully block. But you could wrap your website in an if statement using the `{{ request.remote_ip }}` hubl variable so that if it matches it would show a blank website.
Why do they need to blacklist certain IP's?
^This is a last resort as you lost cacheability
<@U6GNQ7JBU> what if you check {{contact.ip}} (or w/e it is)
Same with `contact` properties
Those need to hit origin to resolve the contact
So you can't cache on the edge
to go off of Luke's question. I know I've had clients ask this as they were looking to use the CMS as a intranet type place
This isn't a good way to build an intranet since anyone can spoof the IP address and get access to your "hidden" content
But will be achievable in the future with content memberships
When will that be in beta? lol #AskingForAFriend
I didn't ask... let me follow up with that question.
I heard there is an event coming up in a month where HubSpot will announce a bunch of new products/beta :stuck_out_tongue:
WHAT! LIES!
:slightly_smiling_face:
My understanding (take with a grain of salt... I could be totally wrong as I'm not on the team working on it) is that we might see something around INBOUND time - ish.
Their response - "they want to prevent competition signing up for free trials and stealing their intellectual property, software company..."
Competition can always just spoof the IP address
Best way is to use phone number authentication
If they want to avoid putting down credit cards
cool - good ideas... Will respond. Thanks Matt
So when you sign up, you need to enter a phone number and your account is only activated when that phone number is verified through a code sent to it
See something like <https://checkmobi.com/pricing.html#/subscription-plans/>

Hi all <!here> , just a quick heads up that we’ve updated our FTP Server to match the new design manager. You now get the same file and folder management system within the FTP that you do in HubSpot, and you can create files in your local environment and see them reflected in HubSpot. For all the details, check out this designers blog post. <https://designers.HubSpot.com/blog/now-live-updated-HubSpot-ftp-for-the-new-design-manager>

Also if you have any feedback on the new FTP, feel free to join <#CBZK16L9L|ftp-feedback>.

just read through, just want a little clarification, I see that our custom file structure is going to show under designs,  is this in addition to the original structure? as in it will appear to us as if a file is in two places?
cool, I'll suggest. I'm assuming they won't want to add that big of a barrier on lead capture forms... but it IS a better solution for what they are trying to do.
Yep, in addition to the original structure. We did that to preserve any old paths people were using.

What about an interim page that you hit before redirecting traffic to the cached pages? So in situations where you know that you want people to get validated (but without breaking the caching of your pages), you send them through a validation page that handles the traffic and decides what to do with it (either block, redirect, etc)

Obviously this isn’t “Secure” in terms of gating content, and people can obviously get around it if they try, but it hides the real destinations behind what amounts to a redirect. and if you noindex / remove from site map / robots.txt block certain pages on a domain / subdomain , that content is essentially invisible except via direct traffic
That would work
Trigger a redirect if a condition is met
Will tuck this little bit of thought experimentation away for the next time I need request / contact params to be used
